Location: central areas of the Deccan plateau
Information: Ashoka holds high significance in treating a host of disorders including menstrual disorders, skin infections, liver problems, stomach problems, jaundice, fever, allergy, asthma, indigestion, constipation, diarrhoea, rheumatic arthritis, bleeding, diabetes etc.
Procedure:
Decoction Preparation:Boil a handful of fresh or dried Ashoka leaves in water until the water reduces to about half its original volume to prepare a decoction .

Internal Consumption:Drink the cooled decoction as recommended by an Ayurvedic practitioner. Ashoka leaf decoction is believed to have various health benefits, especially for women's reproductive health.

It is traditionally used to regulate menstrual cycles, alleviate menstrual cramps, and manage conditions like menorrhagia (heavy menstrual bleeding) and dysmenorrhea (painful periods).
Ashoka leaves are also believed to have astringent and anti-inflammatory properties, which may help in treating diarrhea and other gastrointestinal issues.

Precautions: While Ashoka leaves are generally safe when used appropriately, it's important to use them under the guidance of an Ayurvedic practitioner.

Holistic Approach:In Ayurveda, the use of Ashoka leaves is part of a holistic approach to health and wellness, particularly in addressing women's health issues and promoting overall well-being.
